issue.title: Reduce lock contention in Thread.getAndClearInterrupt

repository.name: openj9-openjdk-jdk
repository.description: Extensions for OpenJDK for Eclipse OpenJ9

issue.body:
Lock contention in `Thread.getAndClearInterrupt` is reduced by
acquiring the lock only when the value of the `Thread.interrupted`
field is `true`.

Related: https://github.com/eclipse-openj9/openj9/issues/20414

timeline_data.body: The current downcall mechanism is quite general as that was the simplest way to implement it for all possible types. We pass the args via JNI so we need to use an array to capture the args or else we need infinite natives for the infinite combinations of params. We had to convert the params to long because its the largest common type for all primitives.
Sounds good, I will modify the test.

issue.title: Reduce available slots to match the upper limit supported by OpenJ9

repository.name: openj9-openjdk-jdk
repository.description: Extensions for OpenJDK for Eclipse OpenJ9

issue.title: Reduce available slots to match the upper limit supported by OpenJ9

timeline_data.body:
Opened the below PRs to address the reported issue:
- JDK24: https://github.com/ibmruntimes/openj9-openjdk-jdk24/pull/6
- JDK-next: https://github.com/ibmruntimes/openj9-openjdk-jdk/pull/912

> The current downcall mechanism is quite general as that was the simplest way to implement it for all possible types. We pass the args via JNI so we need to use an array to capture the args or else we need infinite natives for the infinite combinations of params. We had to convert the params to long because its the largest common type for all primitives.

Our mapping from multiple parameters to a single (or a small number of) arrays should allow for more parameters, not less. What am I missing?

> What am I missing?

[MethodHandle.asCollector](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/21/docs//api/java.base/java/lang/invoke/MethodHandle.html#asCollector(int,java.lang.Class,int)) enforces the following rule from [JVM Spec 4.3.3 - Method Descriptors](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jvms/se17/html/jvms-4.html#jvms-4.3.3): `The number of parameter slots required by the method's descriptor must be less than 256`.

Since we are converting the arguments to an array of `long`s using [MethodHandle.asCollector](https://github.com/eclipse-openj9/openj9/blob/d471e57505e0ee65cf9fc6b5b0b5f7e88f201cc4/jcl/src/java.base/share/classes/openj9/internal/foreign/abi/InternalDowncallHandler.java#L643), the maximum number of elements that can be collected is 128, because each `long` occupies 2 slots, and the total number of slots must be less than 256.
Closing since the PRs in https://github.com/eclipse-openj9/openj9/issues/20355#issuecomment-2575851451 have been merged.

- JDK24: https://github.com/ibmruntimes/openj9-openjdk-jdk24/pull/6
- JDK-next: https://github.com/ibmruntimes/openj9-openjdk-jdk/pull/912

> The current downcall mechanism is quite general as that was the simplest way to implement it for all possible types. We pass the args via JNI so we need to use an array to capture the args or else we need infinite natives for the infinite combinations of params. We had to convert the params to long because its the largest common type for all primitives.

Our mapping from multiple parameters to a single (or a small number of) arrays should allow for more parameters, not less. What am I missing?

> What am I missing?

Since we are converting the arguments to an array of `long`s using [MethodHandle.asCollector](https://github.com/eclipse-openj9/openj9/blob/d471e57505e0ee65cf9fc6b5b0b5f7e88f201cc4/jcl/src/java.base/share/classes/openj9/internal/foreign/abi/InternalDowncallHandler.java#L643), the maximum number of elements that can be collected is 128, because each `long` occupies 2 slots, and the total number of slots must be less than 256.
Closing since the PRs in https://github.com/eclipse-openj9/openj9/issues/20355#issuecomment-2575851451 have been merged.
